IN THE CROWN COURT AT NOTTINGHAM  
R v. Mr H  
Case No: NCT-25-01492  
Sentencing Remarks of His Honour Judge E. J. Delancy  
Filed: 24 September 2025  

The defendant, Mr H, comes before this court for sentence following his conviction by plea on counts 1 and 2 of the indictment: namely, engaging in conduct in preparation for acts of terrorism contrary to section 5(1)(a) of the Terrorism Act 2006, and possessing information of a kind likely to be useful to a person committing or preparing an act of terrorism, contrary to section 58(1)(b) of the same Act. The offending conduct spans from October 2023 until his apprehension by counter-terrorism authorities in April 2025.

Turning to the chronology of proceedings, Mr H was first arrested at approximately 07:16 hours on 17 April 2025, when officers from the East Midlands Special Operations Unit (Counter Terrorism) executed a warrant at the address recorded as Flat 12, Marigold Heights, Leicester Road, Beeston. The warrant, issued pursuant to section 43B of the Terrorism Act 2000, was based on intelligence received jointly from the Security Service and the National Digital Intelligence Support Unit. The informational foundation for the warrant included technical intercept, bulk communications data, and corroboration via the interception of postal items originating from overseas addresses of prior investigative interest.

{INSERT_FACT_SNIPPET_1}

A procedural history must record that, upon his arrest, the defendant was removed for interview to the regional custody suite at Carlton and afforded legal representation. Further searches under Schedule 5 to the 2000 Act were authorised over the following 48 hours. These searches yielded further digital media—six USB flash drives, two external hard drives, and a notebook of hand-written ciphered text—together with miscellaneous computer hardware in various states of disassembly. The digital evidence was triaged by the National Technical Assistance Centre (NTAC), a process hampered by the use of rare encryption algorithms, custom bootloaders, and what the forensic analysts described as “moderately sophisticated attempts at metadata obfuscation.” The court is aware—because this is not the first such case to come before it—of the burden this type of triage imposes. The NDEC’s May 2025 Resource Report noted that their unit was by then facing a backlog of an estimated 9,100 devices awaiting first-look examination, an issue which has become steadily more acute as digital storage becomes both cheaper and more capacious. In the present matter, the unique device signatures associated with Mr H’s IP range were flagged for expedited review after deep packet inspection suggested possible contact with servers previously linked to extremist propaganda dissemination.

A word must be said regarding the duration of pre-charge detention authorised under Schedule 8 of the Terrorism Act 2000. Defence made two unsuccessful applications for release on bail, citing significant delays arising from the time required to break encrypted volumes on the defendant’s devices. The court is not unsympathetic to the pressures on liberty such delay entails. However, I must record that the delay in this case was not occasioned by a lack of diligence on the part of the investigating agencies; rather, it was a necessary corollary of the defendant’s own sustained use of technical measures designed precisely to frustrate prompt access to potential evidence.

The procedural landscape was further complicated by the intersection of ongoing investigations into other persons, including—but not limited to—individuals previously the subject of concern under the Channel and Prevent frameworks. It is not uncommon in such cases for parallel inquiries to result in peripheral material being commingled with primary evidence. In this context, I note that several items seized from Mr H’s premises were ultimately found to be the property of a former flatmate, Mr Daniel K——, who is himself the subject of an open investigation into unrelated alleged shoplifting offences at the Radford Retail Park between 2022 and 2023. Those matters do not touch upon Mr H and have played no part in my deliberations.

At his first appearance in the Nottingham Magistrates’ Court, Mr H was remanded in custody under section 40 of the 2000 Act. He did not apply for bail thereafter, save for a purely formal renewal at the sending hearing. Proceedings in the Crown Court opened with a Plea and Trial Preparation Hearing on 3 July 2025. On that occasion, the defence indicated a potential guilty plea subject to the outcome of two expert reports—one psychiatric, and one addressing the authenticity of the digital evidence compiled in the Crown’s schedule. The reports were not forthcoming until late August, a delay attributed to a combination of staff sickness at the defence’s instructed digital expert firm in Reading and protracted procedural correspondence with the Legal Aid Agency, whose response times have drawn repeated criticism in the criminal courts.

The court desires to record its thanks to both prosecution and defence counsel. Mr Oswald Green represents the Crown Prosecution Service’s Counter Terrorism Division with professional detachment and lucidity, while Mr Rashid Oliver, appearing pursuant to a legal aid Representation Order, has demonstrated both tenacity and courtesy under trying conditions of late service and intermittent disclosure anomalies. Such professionalism is not to be assumed, particularly in a field notable for its public attention, press speculation, and evolving patterns of radicalisation.

{INSERT_FACT_SNIPPET_2}

Delays—regrettable though they are—seem to have been the hallmark of the present matter. The court must record that, owing to bureaucratic error, the listing of the first pre-trial review hearing was vacated, having been double-booked with proceedings in an entirely unrelated multi-defendant conspiracy to burgle case (Regina v. Fahd and nine others, involving offences in West Bridgford, which I am told required the full-day attendance of both the senior listing officer and a duty interpreter summoned at short notice from Derbyshire). While such administrative overlap is far from ideal, I am satisfied that the interruption did not ultimately prejudice either party, and the interests of justice have been served by the subsequent extension of the timetable agreed at the further directions hearing on 18 August 2025.

In considering the credit for plea, the court is bound by the framework established in the Sentencing Council’s Reduction in Sentence for a Guilty Plea Definitive Guideline, and the more specific guidance in the 2023 Sentencing Council Terrorism Offences Guideline. The latter, following the approach laid down in R v. Kahar [2016] EWCA Crim 568 and R v. Lodhi [2006] NSWSC 691 (an authority from Australia, but to which reference has been made in several recent Court of Appeal decisions), makes plain that the objectives of deterrence and public protection are especially weighty in cases of ideological violence, or attempts at such, which are planned over lengthy periods and display sophisticated strategic awareness. In the present matter, the Crown accepts that the factual matrix does not include the highest potential for mass casualties, but the duration of the conduct, and the persistence of the defendant in evading detection, weigh heavily against him.

{INSERT_FACT_SNIPPET_3}

It is perhaps inevitable that, in such cases, the defence invites the court to interpret materials found in the defendant’s possession as susceptible of either innocent or ambiguous purpose. Counsel for Mr H has submitted that several of the technical documents recovered could (in other circumstances) be considered either research for a postgraduate thesis or the detritus of an unfocused but lawful interest in experimental chemistry. In support, they supplied three brief academic references from University College Midlands, indicating that Mr H had attended a handful of public science seminars during 2022-3, and that he had previously submitted a proposal for a citizen-science air quality monitoring project. I am not persuaded—nor did the Crown invite me to be—that these constitute either an exculpatory explanation for possession of terrorism-related materials or a basis for downplaying the seriousness of the offending.

It is also right to record that the Probation Service, whilst under extraordinary caseload and staffing pressures (see the recent findings in the HMIP Thematic Report on Management of Terrorism-Risk Offenders, June 2025), has supplied a detailed pre-sentence risk assessment. The author, Mr Edwin Ray, noted that Mr H’s engagement with probation staff was at times “guarded, yet courteous,” and that he articulated grievances not dissimilar to those observed in a broader pattern among individuals convicted of terrorism offences in the East Midlands conurbation. The report finds that, while there was no evidence of ongoing engagement with non-custodial rehabilitation pathways such as the Channel Programme, the defendant “displayed insight into the abstract risks posed by extremism, but lacked anchor in any practical deradicalisation or disengagement framework.” This echoes the pattern recorded in the 2023 National Counter-Terrorism Risk Register.

{INSERT_FACT_SNIPPET_4}

As the court considers the available evidence, a number of features emerge as aggravating. First, the sustained and non-transient nature of the defendant’s conduct; second, the use of secure communications and anonymisation tools expressly designed to frustrate national security and law enforcement capabilities; and third, the selection of targets or narratives which, by their nature, are intended either to inspire or facilitate violence on an indiscriminate basis. The prosecution places particular weight on the volume of data recovered from hidden or partitioned devices, and the defendant’s apparent proficiency with advanced operating systems and open-source security software. The court is satisfied that the level of planning and operational security demonstrated exceed those of a merely opportunistic actor.

Turning, for completeness, to certain items that found their way into the schedule of unused material: these include a leaflet for a local vegan restaurant, assorted receipts from a general hardware store, and a library card belonging to the defendant’s former co-tenant. The defence submits, not altogether in jest, that these artefacts serve to anchor the defendant in an “ordinary, everyday life.” The court takes no view on the dietary habits of the defendant and, save as they potentially indicate a capacity for normal routine, they play no substantive part in the overall harm or culpability assessed for sentencing purposes.

The character references supplied on behalf of Mr H include, notably, a letter from Mrs Ginny Wheatcroft of the Notts Urban Beekeepers Association, attesting to the defendant’s “quiet diligence,” and a further statement from the Reading Room public library manager, indicating regular punctual attendance at book club events. It is, of course, not unusual for individuals facing sentence for the most grave offences to have also exhibited periods of pro-social or community-minded conduct. As the Court of Appeal observed in R v. Seymore and Fanning [2022] EWCA Crim 824 (a case of aggravated burglary involving life-threatening violence in which the defendants had each coached youth sports teams in their local parish), the absence of prior conviction, or even the presence of affirmatively good character, cannot serve to dilute the need for condign punishment where the gravity of the offending otherwise demands it. In that case, the court found that a custodial sentence of substantial length was “not rendered excessive by the fact of prior good behaviour, however impressive.”

Reference may also be made to the decision in R v. Medlock [2023] EWCA Crim 588, in which the sentencing court gave full weight to the defendant’s positive participation in a local foodbank initiative and voluntary work with Big Issue, yet concluded that these features were at best neutral in the matrix of a serious drugs importation conviction. The present defendant’s offers of community gardening and support for book clubs are not without merit, but must be set alongside the wider context.

{INSERT_FACT_SNIPPET_5}

Counsel for the Crown has advanced written submissions regarding the assessment of harm and the extension of sentence under the extended sentence provisions of section 226A of the Criminal Justice Act 2003. These submissions set out detailed argument on the risk that Mr H would continue to present a danger to the public even after the expiry of an ordinary determinate custodial term. The risk assessment offered is grounded in a variety of factors: the sophistication of his digital footprint, the currency of materials accessed, the degree of operational security maintained in daily routine, and the presence of nascent links identified between the defendant and more established extremist networks. Although no charge has as yet been brought against any such persons, these associations are germane in evaluating future risk.

Defence, for their part, invite comparison to R v. Glasby [2024] EWCA Crim 1040, a case involving preparation for an act of terrorism that was aborted when the defendant confessed his intentions to a close family member. In Glasby, the Court of Appeal ultimately determined that the sentence should not be extended in light of the demonstrable evidence of disengagement. That fact pattern is far removed from the present, where there is no similar evidence of inner transformation, voluntary surrender, or public-spirited contrition.

The present case was twice adjourned for the instruction of competing psychiatric reports. The defence’s instructed consultant, Dr Martha Eccles, reported on 19 August 2025 that Mr H “exhibits patterns of obsessive rumination and belief inflexibility but does not present with a diagnosable mental disorder under either ICD-11 or DSM-5.” The Crown’s adviser, Dr Cormac White, agrees broadly with this assessment but highlights a tendency for “radical self-justification and an absence of, or resistance to, empathy development.” This is consistent with a growing literature on the psychology of lone-actor terrorism, as summarised in the 2024 Home Office Policy Review, Chapter 7.

{INSERT_FACT_SNIPPET_6}

The pre-sentence risk assessment also references input from the Derbyshire Multi-Agency Public Protection Panel (MAPPA), which has outlined provisional proposals for community management in the event that the defendant is eventually released. These include restrictions on internet access, mandatory attendance at a psychological resilience programme, GPS-tagging, and regular reporting to a dedicated Integrated Offender Management keyworker. The MAPPA’s minutes, attached as an exhibit, note significant practical difficulties—among them, the lack of affordable supported housing in the Nottingham urban area, and the considerable delays in psychological intervention currently imposed by the NHS forensic service waiting lists exceeding nine months. These issues, while real, cannot themselves shape the sentence, but they do underscore the challenges that face probation and community partners in managing the residual risk posed by offenders of this profile.

The overall resource strain is compounded by the perpetual shortage of experienced probation officers—a concern echoed by both the Probation Board and trade union representatives in submissions to the Justice Select Committee. The capacity of existing staff to supervise high-risk cases is increasingly stretched, and the ongoing threat posed by “new modalities” of online radicalisation is cited as a contributing factor in the most recent review of the East Midlands region.

{INSERT_FACT_SNIPPET_7}

I record that Mr H is aged 33, with a bachelor’s degree in materials science from Warwick University, and had, prior to the offences, spent six years in a graduate technical role for a national civil engineering firm. His line manager attests in a written character reference to the defendant’s “impeccable time management and quiet but diligent manner,” and states that he was the recipient of a company performance award in 2021. Apparently, Mr H’s resignation from that post was abrupt, occurring a week after a compulsory security clearance re-vetting process brought to light undisclosed contact between the defendant and persons located in an overseas region of concern. Although strictly speaking this episode is of limited probative value, it does serve to place the subsequent conduct in a context of abrupt career change and increasing ideological preoccupation.

Additional community letters submitted to the case file attest to the defendant’s voluntary repair of bicycles for a local children’s charity, as well as ongoing participation in a city litter collection scheme. These matters, while commendable, do not offset the gravity of the offending, nor do they affect the paramount need for public protection.

In considering comparative authority, I am drawn to the Court of Appeal’s guidance in R v. Simmonds [2021] EWCA Crim 1125, which involved possession and dissemination of terrorist-related material, encrypted digital communication, and an incipient plan to manufacture an explosive device using widely available household chemicals. Simmonds had, notably, no previous convictions and presented several character references regarding employment and volunteer activity with a local music group. Despite this, the Court concluded that a lengthy custodial sentence was the only appropriate disposal; the necessity for deterrence and the ever-present risk of recidivism were found to overbear the mitigatory potential of past good conduct.

{INSERT_FACT_SNIPPET_8}

The court also notes, for the sake of transparency, that one of Mr H’s siblings, Ms Eleanor H, is presently the subject of an unrelated set of proceedings before the Magistrates’ Court in Cambridge in connection with an alleged breach of a non-molestation order. There is no evidence, and the court accepts Mr H’s assertion, that the circumstances of his sibling have had any bearing whatsoever on the conduct for which he is now to be sentenced.

It is appropriate, finally, to acknowledge the efforts of various agencies and individuals who have contributed to these proceedings in conditions of mounting public scepticism and constrained resource. The National Probation Service in Nottingham has maintained exceptional standards notwithstanding persistently elevated caseloads. I must also record my appreciation for the contribution of the court ushers and custodial staff, whose professionalism in the daily administration of the criminal justice system is too rarely noted in official record, and who, in this case, have had to accommodate several last-minute listing changes owing to the fire alarm malfunctions in Courtroom 2.

Turning, then, to the next stage. The court has determined that sentencing should not proceed without the benefit of a comprehensive pre-sentence report, with specific reference to the viability of an Extended Determinate Sentence and the proposed measures for community risk management in compliance with the MAPPA framework. I direct that such report be prepared by the National Probation Service and filed no later than 14 days prior to the adjourned sentencing date. The report should explicitly address the prospect of deradicalisation provision, technological risk mitigation, and the scope for structured reintegration interventions, in addition to commenting on the practical capacity of the relevant agencies to deliver any supervision or support required.

These are the orders of the court.
